College of New Energy China University of Petroleum (East China) 66 West Changjiang Road Qingdao PR China Selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) technology is an effective process for industrial flue gas denitrification. Ce-based catalysts are widely studied due to their excellent redox properties and superior oxygen storage and release capacity (OSC). However, the unavoidable presence of SO2 and H2O in the coal-fired flue gas leads to their limitations in the application of denitrification technology. SO2 poisoning not only causes the formation of metal sulfates, but its synergistic interaction with H2O also results in the deposition of ammonium sulfate species. All this leads to severe deactivation of Ce-based catalysts in NH3-SCR. The development of Ce-based catalysts with excellent sulfur and water resistance is an urgent requirement for SCR technology. This review elucidates the poisoning mechanism of SO2, and analyzes the effects of metals/non-metals modification and structural optimization on the anti-SO2 performance of Ce-based catalysts. This provides the reference and guidance for the subsequent development of Ce-based catalysts resistance to SO2. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ce-based catalysts SO2 resistance NH3-SCR Reaction mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction NO x , as one of the atmospheric pollutants, not only causes environmental problems such as haze, near-surface ozone and particulate matter (PM) [1,2], but also seriously impacts human health. Selective catalytic reduction NO x with ammonia (NH3-SCR) technology is one of the most effective means of removing NO x from stationary and mobile sources emissions. Traditional V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalyst is the most widely deployed in commerce due to its excellent NH3-SCR reaction activity and high N2 selectivity at 300–400 °C [3,4]. However, V2O5 as the active component of vanadium-based catalysts is biotoxic and the deactivated catalysts must be disposed as hazardous waste, which are drawbacks that cannot be avoided and overcome [5]. The focus of related studies gradually shifted to non-vanadium-based catalysts. Many researchers have been making great efforts to find efficient and environmentally friendly catalysts. Noble metal (Pt [6,7], Pd [8–10], Rh [11], Ag [12–15], etc.) catalysts performed excellent catalytic activity for NH3-SCR. However, the expensive cost and rare stock of noble metals does not support their application in industrial production. Ce-based catalysts, including mixed oxides, derivatives of MOFs and supported or doped Ce-based catalysts, have the significant redox ability of the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pair and the superior OSC [16]. They attract much attention because of their high NO x conversion, low price and high thermal stability Tables S1 and S2 demonstrate the high reactivity of Ce-based catalysts at medium-high temperatures (>200 °C) and low temperatures (<200 °C), respectively. A superior performance at low temperatures meets the requirements of sectors that emit exhaust gas with lower temperature. Currently, Ce-based catalysts are promising alternatives to V-based catalysts and can exhibit excellent activity especially at low temperatures. However, SO2 and H2O are inevitably present in industrial flue gases, which cause deactivation of Ce-based catalysts and severely restrict their industrial application and development. Xu et al. [17] found that the NO x conversion of the Ce/TiO2 decreased to 34.5 % within 48 h, with the introduction of 150 ppm SO2 at 300 °C. Our group reported that the NH3-SCR activities of Ce20Ti catalyst were 42.3 % and 40 % at 350 °C after feeding 200 ppm and 500 ppm SO2 and 10 % H2O [18,19], respectively. To solve the problem of catalyst poisoning fundamentally, researchers have been exploring its deactivation mechanisms. Competitive adsorption of H2O and NH3 is a major reason for water toxicity. Song [20] and Hao [21] et al. reported that the activity of the catalysts returned to the initial level after cutting off the supply of H2O. Therefore, its competitive effect in the presence of water alone is reversible inactivation. Generally, the coexistence of H2O and SO2 causes more severe deactivation on Ce-based catalysts than SO2 alone. This is due to the reaction of H2O, NH3 and SO2 in the presence of O2, thus water also deeply involved in the formation of ammonium bisulfate (ABS) species, which leads to deactivation of SCR catalysts at low-temperatures. SO2 poisoning is divided into two main categories: (1) Reversible deactivation due to ammonium sulfate (AS) and ABS deposition, which decomposes over 300 °C. The formation of them occupies the active sites and hinders the adsorption of reactive gases on the catalyst surface. (2) The active species of catalysts reacts with SO2 to form metal sulfates, causing irreversible deactivation. So far, some good review articles have been reported on recent advances in NH3-SCR. These reviews elaborated recent researches on the use of supported and mixed transition metal oxide catalysts to enhance the performance and anti-poisoning capabilities of NH3-SCR reaction [1,22–33]. However, there are few systematic summaries of the SO2 poisoning mechanisms of Ce-based catalysts and specific schemes to improve sulfur and water resistance. Different optimized systems have different anti-SO2 mechanisms, and a detailed understanding of their anti-SO2 mechanisms will be helpful for further screening and development of suitable anti-sulfur catalysts. In this study, SO2 deactivation mechanisms of Ce-based catalysts were explored in detail. The means of promoting their tolerance of SO2 and H2O, such as modification and structure optimization, as well as resistance mechanisms were discussed. Fig. 1 shows a knowledge co-occurrence map of research hotspots based on the frequent keywords, including SO2, modification, sulfate, mechanism, etc., in the research database of Ce-based catalysts for NH3-SCR applications in recent years. Hopefully, this review can offer valuable insights and strategies for the design of future Ce-based catalysts with superior efficiency and resistance to SO2. 2 SO2 poisoning mechanisms The species affecting the deactivation of Ce-based catalysts varied with the reaction temperature. AS and ABS, generated by the synergistic action of SO2 and H2O in the presence of O2, were deposited on Ce-based catalysts at low temperatures. Among them, ABS is the main cause of deactivation due to its coverage that occupies the active sites of the catalyst. Since AS and ABS decompose over 300 °C [34], metal sulfates turn out to be the dominant and worse species causing catalyst deactivation with increasing temperature. Exploring the SO2 poisoning mechanism of Ce-based catalysts at different reaction temperatures can help to better achieve the application of Ce-based catalysts under various temperature conditions. 2.1 Deposition of ABS ABS deposition is one of reasons of sulfur poisoning at low temperatures. ABS undergoes a phase transition at around 147 °C, from solid to liquid, and eventually becomes sticky and corrosive [35–38]. This gives rise to covering of active sites and blockage of pores on metal oxide catalysts. The formation of ABS reduced the open space above the metal sites from 0.47 nm to 0.23 nm [39]. Since the molecular diameters of NH3 and NO were 0.37 nm and 0.32 nm, respectively, the steric hindrance created by ABS above the catalyst made it difficult for the reaction gases to approach the active sites. Moreover, the strong chemical interaction between ABS and metal sites was also a factor that affected NH3-SCR activity. A recent study by Guo's group showed that NH4 + and HSO4 − could bond with different metal ions respectively to undermine the capacity of adsorption [40]. An et al. [41] reported that NO x conversion sharply decreased because of inert NH4 + deposition. Thus, solving the problem of ABS deposition is the challenge to improve SCR reactivity at low temperatures. ABS is extremely easy to form on V-based catalysts, which are different from Ce-based catalysts, due to their ability to oxidize SO2 [42,43]. Currently, few studies have been conducted to investigate the generation process of ABS on Ce-based catalysts, and an accurate and detailed knowledge of the process is still lacking. As a result, attention was focused on the decomposition process of ABS. Due to the strongly temperature sensitive of ABS decomposition, it begins to decompose at >300 °C [37,38,44,45]. This results in a non-significant effect of ABS on denitrification activity at medium-high temperatures, but a drastic deactivation of that at low temperatures. In order to accelerate the decomposition of ABS, many researchers have been exploring its process extensively [34,46–50]. It was reported that NH4 + continued to engage in the NH3-SCR reaction, while SO4 2− bound to the metal sites in the form of metal sulfates [40,51,52]. As the temperature increased, ABS interacted with CeO2, leading to the formation of Ce2(SO4)3 species on the surface, accompanied by the release of NH3 (Eq. (1)) [53]. (1) 2 N H 4 H S O 4 + C e O 2 → 2 N H 3 + C e 2 ( S O 4 ) 3 + 2 H 2 O Ren et al. [54] used density functional theory (DFT) to investigate the decomposition of ABS. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), one of the NH bonds in NH4 + broke to form NH3 and sulfate radical remained on the catalyst surface. It could be seen from Fig. 2(b) that the sulfate radical can be decomposed. One of the O ions combined with two H ions to form H2O, and the residual SO3 combined with surface lattice oxygen to form metal sulfate, which was the main cause of irreversible catalyst deactivation. This was consistent with their team's findings on the LaMnO3 catalyst (Fig. 2(c-d)) [55]. Based on studies by Fan [56], Li [57] and Guo [58] et al., the decomposition of ABS could be roughly divided into three steps (Fig. 3 ): (1) Desorption of H2O molecules from ABS (Eq. (2)); (2) Dissociation and release of NH3. By taking part in NH3-SCR reaction, this part of ammonia could be consumed (Eq. (3)); (3) The catalyst was rejuvenated by liberating SO3 (Eq. (4a)) or SO2 + 1/2 O2 (Eq. (4b)) from its surface. (2) * N H 4 H S O 4 → H 2 O + * S O 3 − N H 3 (3) * S O 3 − N H 3 → * S O 3 + N H 3 (4a) * S O 3 → * + S O 3 (4b) * S O 3 → * + S O 2 + 1 / 2 O 2 Considering the fact that the chemical reaction of ammonia with sulfur oxides is thermodynamically favorable [36], the formation of ABS in NH3-SCR reactions seems to be an unavoidable problem. Thus, from the perspective of alleviation ABS poisoning, mitigating ABS deposition and accelerating ABS decomposition are the basic ideas. Ma et al. [39] found that the amount of ABS on the CeO2 surface remained constant even after 1000 h in the presence of SO2. Yu et al. [59] also reported a stable ABS content on γ-Fe2O3 over 216 h. From these phenomena, it is clear that the deposition and decomposition of ABS on the catalyst surface have reached an equilibrium. Therefore, understanding the accumulation and decomposition of ABS and constructing the deposition/decomposition equilibrium are important to solve the problem of poor NH3-SCR activity at low temperatures. 2.2 Formation of metal sulfates Over time and temperature, the sulfur species on Ce-based catalysts evolved during the reaction. An et al. [41]. found that ABS formed metal sulfates during decomposition. Wu et al. [60] observed sub-bulk and bulk sulfates on the CeO2 catalyst by in situ DRIFTS. Du et al. [61] reported that the sulfates on the surface of Ce-Ti oxides could be highly dispersed Ce2(SO4)3 or Ce(SO4)2. SO2 competed with NH3 and NO for adsorption, leading to preferential adsorption of SO2 and formation of bidentate mononuclear sulfate on catalysts surface. As shown in Eq. (5) [62], SO2 was oxidized to sulfate species by reducing Ce4+ to Ce3+: (5) 2 C e O 2 + 3 S O 2 + O 2 → C e 2 ( S O 4 ) 3 The distribution of sulfur was strongly related to that of Ce [17]. Wu et al. [60] showed through DFT studies that on CeO2, monodentate sulfates were readily formed under aerobic conditions, while bidentate sulfates tended to be formed under anaerobic conditions. There are two accounts of the effect of sulfates on catalysts. Bidentate sulfates impeded the production of NO derivatives but had little effect on NH3 adsorption [63]. Liu et al. [64] emphasized that the sulfation could cause geometric deformation on the surface of CeTiO x catalyst. It was reported that the formation of Ce2(SO4)3 and Ce(SO4)2 was the identified as the primary cause of the permanent deactivation on Ce-based catalysts. Besides, there was also evidence that sulfation was a promoter of acidity on metal oxide catalyst, which enhanced the performance of NH3-SCR reaction [52]. This debate illustrated that sulfation of active components not only always had negative effects. For different kinds of Ce-based catalysts, different deactivation mechanisms have been published, but no consensus has been agreed upon. The unique properties of metal sulfates provide ideas for the development of future sulfur-resistant catalysts. 2.2.1 Promoted effects It was reported that the additional introduction of SO2 or metal sulfates enhanced NH3-SCR reactivity [65–67]. Sulfates promoted the adsorption of H2O. Generally, H2O molecules were present in combination with metal atoms or sulfur atoms of sulfates to form Brønsted acid sites [68–72]. One way was that the S=O bonds in the bidentate sulfates were broken and combined with H atoms in the H2O molecules to form S-OH bonds [73]. The other was that the transfer of the H atoms to the S-O bonds broke the bond between sulfate and metal atom [66,67,74]. In this case, the remaining O and H atoms of the H2O molecules were present as ·OH on the metal sites. An [41] and Zhang [75] et al. disclosed that sulfates on the surface of CeO2 did increase its reactivity due to the production of abundant Brønsted acidity. A negative peak attributed to SO4 2− at 1356cm−1 were detected through in situ DRIFT spectra of the adsorption of NH3 for sulfated Ce/TiO2, suggesting that it was covered by adsorbed NH3 [76,77]. Thus, the method of modulating the catalyst surface acidity by the sulfation provides ideas for improving the NH3-SCR reaction. In contrast to fresh catalysts where the metal sites exhibited both adsorption and activation properties, sulfated catalysts separated acid sites from redox sites [51], coordinating the roles of both [78,79]. Chen et al. [80] found that NH3 and NO were mainly adsorbed on SO4 2− and Ce4+, respectively. As a result, the NH3 collision probability with NO was reduced. This prevented the over oxidation of NH3 to some extent. The introduction of SO2 to increase NO x conversion was associated not only with the promotion of NH3 adsorption to enhance the SCR reaction, but also with the inhibition of the CO reaction (the catalytic oxidation of NH3 to NO) [76]. Wang et al. [81] found that combining organic-like sulfate groups with Fe-O-Ce resulted in strong electronic interactions between both of them, which changed the redox properties of the catalysts. The redox cycle between Fe3+ and Ce4+ was interrupted by the sulfate groups, which inhibited the oxidation of NH3 at medium-high temperatures and led to an excellent performance in NO x conversion. The production of sulfates did impair the reducibility of the metal sites, especially poor effect on nitrate adsorption, but the generated Ce2(SO4)3 added complementary redox sites. Due to the strong electron affinity of the S=O bonds and the violent electronic perturbations produced by SO4 2−, new adsorption sites were provided for nitrate species with negative electron [81]. Wu et al. [60] showed that anaerobic SO2 treatment promoted the partial reduction of Ce species on the CeO2 surface, and led to the formation of oxygen vacancies and increased the number of redox oxygen species. Sulfate species formed on CeO2-rod catalyst could contribute new redox sites to participate in the reaction. For SO4 2−/CeO2-SG (solid-grinding), new active species (*ON-O* and cis-N2O2 2−) were created due to the proper electron attraction of SO4 2− [82]. Although nitrate species did not be detected, the new species easily reacted with NH3 and promoted the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. 2.2.2 Inhibited effects The transformation of surface sulfate to bulk or large particle sulfate exposed catalysts to a deeper degree of deactivation. At below 350 °C, surface adsorbed or amorphous sulfates were formed on CeO2; when the temperature at 350–450 °C, bulk-likde sulfates were formed in the subsurface layer or deeper interior of CeO2 [83]. Sulfates caused changes in the morphology and structure of catalysts. It was observed via TEM that many obvious amorphous bumps of cerium sulfates were formed on the surface of CeO2 after sulfation [39]. And cerium sulfates led to specific area and pore volume to decrease [82,83]. With a further increase in temperature, the surface metal sulfates would further accumulate and crystallize on the catalyst and the interaction between sulfates and CeO2 deepened [84]. At 550 °C, the bulk phase Ce(SO4)2 and CeOSO4, which were observed through XRD, appeared, causing severer deactivation. Sulfate affected NO molecules adsorbed on the surface of catalyst to generate key intermediate species of SCR reaction, such as NO+,NO2 −,NO2 and NO3 −. O atoms used to bridge NO and Ce ions were covered by SO4 2− after sulfation [41,79], hindering NO adsorption [60] and oxidation as well as activation of nitrate species. Xiao et al. [76] reported that sulfation facilitated NH3 adsorption but almost completely depressed NO adsorption on Ce/TiO2. Nitrite was adsorbed on the surface of catalyst in the nitro form only via the N atom since the exposed O atom disappeared. He et al. [85] found that the introduction of SO2 and H2O generated relatively stable and inactive nitrate species, deactivating the catalyst active sites. In addition, chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) is essential for the oxidation of ability of NO to NO2, which is a key species of “fast SCR” reaction process. The presence of metal sulfates also led to a decrease in the proportion of Oα, rendering it difficult for the “fast SCR” reaction to occur. Sulfation promoted NH3 adsorption but interfered with its activation process, which is an important process of NH3-SCR [86–89]. Liu et al. [64] researched energy profiles for NH3-SCR reaction on sulfated Ti-doped CeO2 solid solution, and found that its NH bonds dissociation barrier of NH3 was higher than that of clean surface. This was because sulfates competed with NH3 for adsorption sites and decreased the interaction between NH3 and the catalyst surface, thus more energy required for NH bonds dissociation. Cerium was proved that, as active center of NH3-SCR reaction, was easily to react with SO2 [62]. Due to sulfur poisoning, the interconversion between valence states of Ce, which was simultaneously accompanied by creating oxygen vacancies, was blocked. Ji et al. [82] reported that the formation energy of oxygen vacancy on CeO2 (111) was only 2.31 eV, while that increased to 3.48 eV when the SO4 2− group was attached to the Ce atom. The redox properties of CeO2 catalysts were suppressed by the strong electron-withdrawal effect of SO4 2−, which obstructed the formation of oxygen vacancies. Xu et al. [17] discussed that deactivation of a Ce/TiO2 catalyst by SO2, and found that Ce(SO4)2 and Ce2(SO4)3 inhibited the formation of nitrate species and cut off the redox properties between Ce3+ and Ce4+. This was similarly found by Ma et al. [90]. Although SO2 has both promoted and inhibited effects on Ce-based catalysts, the adverse impacts caused by deactivation still account for the majority in practical industrial applications. Thus, the development of catalysts with anti-SO2 poisoning properties is of great importance. 3 Strategies and mechanisms to reduce SO2 poisoning 3.1 Metal modification 3.1.1 Fe modification Fe, as a structural and electronic promoter with low price [91], can not only enlarge the specific surface area and change the crystal structure of the catalyst, but also improve the redox properties and acidity of the catalyst [92–94]. Fe modification could reduce the size of the support particles and enable better dispersion of the active components [95]. Furthermore, the addition of Fe increased oxygen defects [96] content and the proportion of metal oxides with higher valence states [97]. A novel Fe-doped CePO4 catalyst was researched by Zeng et al. [98] As shown in Fig. 4 (a), NH3-TPD results showed that the amount of weakly adsorbed NH3 (desorption temperature below 300 °C) on Fe-doped CePO4 was the highest, suggesting that could enhance NH3 activation. And adding Fe could induce the generation of F e 3 + + C e 3 + ↔ F e 2 + + C e 4 + redox cycles to enhance the redox properties of the catalyst, which was the main reason for a superior NH3-SCR activity (Fig. 4(b)). And modifying Fe could inhibit the adsorption of SO2 and H2O as well as the formation of sulfate species [86]. Ce@Ce-Fe Prussian blue analogues with mesopore characteristic and double-cone structure exhibited exceptional resistance to H2O and SO2 due to its high Fe content [99]. Sun et al. [100] reported that the NH3-SCR performance of Fe2CeZr2O x was only reduced by less than 10 % in the presence of SO2 and H2O. And after cutting off the feed of SO2 and H2O for 3 h, the NO x conversion could recover to the initial value, while the CeZr2O x catalyst still remained low. The formation of sulfate species on the Fe-Mn-Ce/Al2O3 catalyst could be prevented by Fe modification, and the catalyst showed a high performance [101]. The mechanism of doping Fe to improve SO2 tolerance was discussed in detail. Kang et al. [102] were the first to analyze the SO2 resistance mechanism of Ce-based vanadate catalysts by using gas breakthrough analysis. As shown in Fig. 5 (a-b) FeδCe1-δVO4 required a shorter time to reach saturation of adsorbed SO2 and smaller SO2 adsorption compared to Ce1-δVO4 (31 μmol/g and 118 μmol/g on FeδCe1-δVO4 and Ce1-δVO4, respectively), both of which demonstrated that doping Fe was less susceptible to adsorb SO2 on the Ce1-δVO4 catalyst. As a result, as shown in Fig. 5(c), the active sites and reaction intermediates on the FeδCe1-δVO4 were not affected by the surface sulfate species, which allowed the reaction to proceed smoothly through the E-R mechanism. Zhang et al. [103] observed that the increments of Ce3+ and Oα (due to the formation of Ce2(SO4)3) on the sulfated CeFeW catalyst were smaller than those on the sulfated CeW. This was due to doping Fe changed the electron distribution around the CeO2 and inhibited the oxidation of SO2 to Ce2(SO4)3 by Ce4+ (Fig. 6 (a)). Furthermore, the faster consumption of NH4 + attributed to ABS on CeFeW was contributed to the fact that Fe promoted NO adsorption and activation to produce more NO2, thus accelerating behaviors of ABS decomposition. The reactions between pre-adsorbed NH3 and NO+SO2+O2 were also studied (Fig. 6(b-c)). Compared to the peaks belonging to NH3 (1592 and 1184 cm−1) and NH4 + (1420 and 1662 cm−1) on CeW catalyst, which disappeared within 9 min and 20 min, respectively, the peaks on CeFeW catalyst disappeared rapidly after the feeding of NO. This indicated that SO2 had little effect on the reaction between adsorbed NH3 and gaseous NO on CeFeW, while it significantly inhibited the reaction on CeW. Besides, FeO x usually interacts with other metal oxides to improve the resistance to H2O and SO2 of catalysts. The interaction between MnO x and FeO x on S-MnFeCoCe/Ti/Si catalyst induced electron migration between Fe and Mn ions ( F e 2 + + M n 4 + ↔ F e 3 + + M n 3 + ) [104]. Mn3+ was more conducive to resistance to SO2 poisoning [105] due to its ability to inhibit the oxidation of SO2 to SO3 by Mn4+. Wang et al. [106] found that the uniformly dispersed Fe and Co species caused SO2 to remain in the surface and subsurface layers or unstable sulfates, which prevented its diffusion into the inner layers of the Mn/Ce-TiO2 catalyst. Moreover, it was difficult to adsorb NO on 2Fe4Co-MCT in the presence of SO2. So, it was hypothesized that the reaction proceeded via the Eley-Rideal mechanism, whereby adsorbed NH3 reacted with gaseous NO to form unstable NH4NO2, and then rapidly decomposed to N2 and H2O. A novel MnO x -CeO2 catalyst modified by Nb5+ and Fe3+ was designed by Long et al. [107] Co-doping of Nb5+ and Fe3+ increased the surface acidity of the catalyst, which resulted in a higher adsorption capacity of NH3 and a lower competitive adsorption of SO2 with NH3. Simultaneously, its influenced electron density around S atoms in ABS, favoring the decomposition of HSO4 − deposited on the surface to SO2. It was reported that SO2 reacted preferentially with Nb instead of Mn and Ce [108]. And the addition of Fe made this phenomenon more pronounced, thus reducing sulfates species on the catalyst surface. 3.1.2 Cu modification Copper had the advantages of being economical, easily accessible and widely used. It is commonly utilized in low-temperature NH3-SCR reactions due to its remarkable oxidizing ability. Copper oxide facilitated the formation of double redox pairs, which could be a key factor in the excellent performance of NH3-SCR [109]. And the introduction of Cu into Ce-based catalysts could improve their reactivity in the presence of SO2. Cu modified on NbCe was reported to act as a highly efficient catalyst with good SO2 tolerance capability [110]. Liu et al. [111] introduced Cu into V/Ce-Ti catalysts and found that good resistance to SO2 and H2O was obtained. The promotion mechanism of anti-SO2 by Cu doping in Ce-based catalysts was proposed. Wang et al. [112] reported that copper species was mainly present in the form of non-isolated Cu+ and isolated Cu2+, and the isolated Cu2+ ions acted as adsorption and dissociation centers of reactive oxygen species to promote NO oxidation. The SO4 2− group tended to bind to Cu2+ that substituted Ce4+ and dissolved in the CeO2 lattice, effectively avoiding the poisoning of the Ce4+ active sites [113]. Zhang et al. [114] detected that the modification of copper in the CeTiO x catalyst could exhibit more than 90 % NO x conversion with a wide temperature window (170–425 °C) and better SO2/H2O resistance even at high GHSV condition. This was also associated with the presence of Cu2+. Yang et al. [115] found that a moderate amount of copper doping prevented SO2 adsorption and oxidation, and competitive adsorption of SO2 barely affected NO adsorption. As a result, Cu0.2Ce/CACCNTs catalyst had great SO2 resistance and lost less than 10 % of SCR activity. In addition, Cu increased not only the strength and number of acidic sites [110,116,117], but also the number of oxygen vacancies, the ratio of Ce3+, and the content of chemisorbed oxygen [111,114], which accelerated the oxidation of NO to NO2 and facilitated the “fast SCR” reaction. The catalysts improved NH3-SCR reactivity and the tolerance of sulfur and water toxicity under the combined effect of many factors. Adding Cu species to catalysts made the oxygen species more active [118]. The NH3 oxidizing capacity significantly promoted with increasing Cu loading [117]. However, excess Cu content led to a significant decrease in the NH3 activation energy barrier [119], resulting in the excessive oxidation of NH3 and the inhibition of NO reduction [120]. Therefore, controlling the doping amount of Cu had a crucial role in improving the SCR activity as well as the sulfur and water resistance. 3.1.3 W modification Lewis acid sites were predominantly on CeO2, whereas a statistically significant increase in Brønsted acid sites generated on W [121], providing extra medium-strong acid amount. The increase in Brønsted acid sites could remarkably improve NH3 adsorption capacity and the low-temperature SCR activity. Although the addition of W led to a decrease in the redox capacity of the catalyst, the increase in acidity, especially in the Brønsted acid sites [122–125], gave the catalyst a high surface acidity to compensate for the lack of redox properties [126]. Therefore, SO2 adsorption did not affect NH3 adsorption and activation. And the decrease in oxidizing capacity prevented the oxidation of SO2 to SO4 2− and inhibited the formation of large amounts of sulfates. Li et al. [127] found that doping 5 wt.% WO3 in V/Ce/Ti catalyst exhibited high SO2 resistance. This was due to the fact that the addition of WO3 greatly reduced the catalyst alkalinity, resulting in less adsorbed acidic SO2 species. Moreover, WO3 was more favorable for trapping electrons from neighboring V and Ce, producing more Ce3+ species. This could make it more difficult for ABS to trap electrons from Ce, reducing its thermal stability. Thus, ABS was completely consumed by NO + O2, and the dynamic equilibrium was achieved. And, it was reported that due to the strong interaction between W and SO4 2−, the higher electron cloud density positively influenced the conversion of SO4 2− to SO2 [53]. The tungsten-doped CeO2/TiO2 catalyst prepared by Kwon et al. [128] was able to form fewer sulfates on the surface and showed a satisfactory sulfur resistance. Li et al. [129] reported that the moderate amount of tungsten doping not only enlarged the specific surface area of the catalyst, but also inhibited the growth of fluorite structure CeO2, facilitating the dispersion of Ce on the catalyst. And the NO x conversion of the W-doped catalyst could still reach more than 94 % in the presence of 100 ppm SO2 for 18 h. Liu et al. [130] revealed that Ce3W2SbO x catalyst with strong interaction of Ce, W and Sb showed remarkably improved SO2 tolerance. Chen et al. [131] also found that the interaction between Ce and W played an important role in NH3-SCR and anti-SO2 poisoning. 3.1.4 Other metals modification Mn was also commonly used in SCR catalysts due to its multivalent states. It was studied that the formation of bisulfate was related to the hydroxyl group ( − O H + S O 2 → H S O 3 − ) [132]. Xu et al. [133] found that the content of O that attributed to the hydroxyl group on MnCe/GACCNTs catalyst dropped. This was confirmed by the fact that the presence of Mn had a positive significance on the sulfur resistance of Ce-based catalysts. And S species on the MnCe/GACCNTs catalyst was mostly present in the low valence state (S4+) rather than the high valence state (S6+) after being oxidized. In addition, Mn doping in Ce-based catalysts acted as a sacrificial agent, preferentially reacting with SO2 and protecting the Ce active site from sulfur poisoning [134]. Xu et al. [135] reported that the homogeneous distribution of Mn and Ce species resulted in the inability of the sulfates to be retained on the catalyst surface. Rare earth elements are also often used as promoters for catalysts. The team of Liu et al. [62] reported that the electronic transfer of S m 2 + + C e 4 + ↔ S m 3 + + C e 3 + on SmCeTi catalyst was responsible for good SO2 tolerance, because of the inhibition of electron transfer from adsorbed SO2 to Ce4+ (Fig. 7 (a)). And they also found that Sm in the Ti/CeSm catalyst played a role in inhibiting (NH4)2SO4, NH4HSO4, Ce(SO4)2 [136]. As shown in Fig. 7(b-d), after adsorption of SO2 +O2, the peaks at 1120, 1207, 993 and 905 cm−1 (Fig. 7(b)), and 1126 and 993 cm−1 (Fig. 7(c)), and 1139 cm−1 (Fig. 7(d)) attributed to bulk sulfate species was detected. It showed that the intensity of the peak in Ti/CeSm was weakened, suggesting that the modification of Sm species also inhibited the formation of bulk sulfate. Xie et al. [137] showed that (NH4)2SO4, which caused the catalyst poisoning, was less deposited and more easily decomposed after SmO x addition. DFT result revealed that the adsorption energy of SO2 on Sm2O3(001) was lower than CeO2(110) [138], thus Sm doping in the Ce-based catalysts could effectively suppress SO2 adsorption [139]. In addition, other rare earth elements, such as Pr [140], Ho [139,141,142] and Tm [143], doped in Ce-based catalysts also showed excellent SO2 tolerance. The introduction of Nb, Mo, Co, Cr, Sb, Sn and Zr as promoters or active components to enhance the SO2 resistance of NH3-SCR catalysts was also investigated. The denitrification activities in the presence of SO2 are listed in Table 1 . 3.2 Non-metal modification Previous works revealed that phosphorus exhibited high acidity, thermal stability, and proton conductivity [177,178], which improved the NH3-SCR reaction activity of the CeO2 catalyst [179–181]. P doping could enhance the synergistic interaction between Mn and Ce on the MnO x -CeO2/P-CA catalyst, leading to the higher formation of Mn4+, Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen [182]. The generation of NO complexes on the P-doped catalyst was maintained even when SO2 inhibited NO adsorption and oxidation, which fully ensured that the reaction could proceed via the l-H mechanism. Wang et al. [177] found that the adsorbed NH3 was able to complete the activation process to participate in the SCR reaction because the surface oxygen of the main active phase maintained a high mobility, during the sulfation process of the Cu-Ce oxide catalyst with NbOPO4 as the support. Yao et al. [183] reported that the Ce-O-P catalyst prepared by a sol-gel method could supplement the active oxygen ions consumed by SO2 capture, thereby showing an outstanding redox performance. Zeng et al. [184] loaded CeO2 onto mesoporous P-doped TiO2 with strong acidity and high stability, and found that it was highly resistant to H2O and SO2 at medium-high temperatures. Si species provides higher surface acidity and further diminishes the alkalinity of catalysts [185]. Tan et al. [186] designed a CeSi2 catalyst with Ce-O-Si structure and abundant surface hydroxyl groups, reducing the SO2 adsorption capacity that prevents SO2 poisoning from the prerequisite step. The same phenomenon was observed on the Si-doped MnCe/Ti catalyst by Qing et al. [187], and the regulation mechanism for SiO2 was shown in Fig. 8 (c). The NH3-SCR reaction mechanism on fresh and sulfated CeSi2 catalysts was also investigated. As could be seen in Fig. 8(a), after cutting off NH3 and introducing NO+O2, the NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (1442 and 1608 cm−1) was rapidly consumed, indicating that the reaction proceeded efficiently through the E-R mechanism. The sulfated CeSi2 still exhibited the same reaction (Fig. 8(b)), suggesting that sulfation did not have an effect on the E-R mechanism. In addition, SiO2 doping could reduce the active metal valence of the catalyst. After doping with SiO2, the Mn4+ content of the MnO x catalyst was reduced, allowing SO2 to react less readily with the active component Mn [188]. Liu et al. [189] also had the same finding in the Ce/TiO2-SiO2 catalyst: the strong interaction of Ti and Si stimulated the transformation of Ce4+ to Ce3+. Under the combined effect of SO2 and H2O, the NO x conversion of Mn/CeSiO x catalyst was slightly decreased; after cutting off the supply of SO2 and H2O, it recovered rapidly [190]. In addition, there were other non-metal elements that could be employed as dopants to modulate the sulfur resistance of Ce-based catalysts. Liu et al. [191] found that S doping had a positive effect on SO2 poisoning resistance of Ce-based catalysts because sulfur species could cause strong electronic perturbations to the catalyst support and stimulate charges transfer [192]. Carbon doping in the CeZrO2- x catalyst could insulate the metal atoms with partial ammonium sulfate attachment, resulting in poor thermal stability of ammonium sulfate [193]. The formation of more zirconium sulfate not only protected the active cerium, but also provided more Brønsted acid sites. And the generation of unstable ammonium sulfate decomposed more easily. These all were accountable for the lower deactivation of the catalyst. 3.3 Optimize structure Catalytic performance was also related to the shape and structure of the catalysts [78]. In recent years, many studies found that changing structures of catalysts could result in superior physical texture characteristics and more stable chemical properties. This method played a very vital role in anti-sulfur poisoning. The core-shell structure has attracted much attention because of its large specific surface area, the close integration of the core-shell components, and the protective effect of the shell material on the core material [194,195]. The interaction between Ce and the support or other metal atoms was enhanced by core-shell structure [196,197]. The protective effect of the shell encapsulating the core was more pronounced in the presence of SO2, which is considerably beneficial for the sulfur resistance of catalysts. Huang et al. [198], Zhang et al. [199] (Fig. 9 (a)) and Yao et al. [200] (Fig. 9(b)) found that the core-shell structure separated the active components from the shell, which inhibited the SO2 adsorption and the deposition of sulfate species on the active sites of the core, thus providing significant protection for core. Besides, as shown in Fig. 9(c), a novel yolk-shell Ce@Mn@TiO x , which evolved from the core-shell structure, successfully separated redox sites from acidic sites [201]. The MnO x intercalation induced interfacial electronic interactions between Ce and Mn, and the TiO2 shell defended against water and sulfur species while ensuring enhanced NH3 adsorption. Chen et al. [122] prepared a unique core-shell W@CeO2 catalyst with a hollow structure. This catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity and resistance to SO2 and H2O compared to W@CeO2 catalyst solid spheres (Fig. 9(d)). Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have a huge advantage than conventional metal oxide catalysts in terms of specific surface area. It is widely used in SCR due to its regular porosity and high porosity, stable backbone, low density and high chemical ductility, which allows for a high degree of dispersion and exposure of metal sites [202,203]. Currently, Jemal et al. [204] synthesized a UiO-66(Ce) without the need for energy and other chemicals by simply mixing an aqueous solution of Ce(IV) and an aqueous suspension of the insoluble terephthalic acid at room temperature. This approach laid a considerable foundation for the subsequent synthesis of MOFs materials at room temperature. Wang et al. [205] achieved a tight coupling of acidic and redox sites through anchoring Ce sitting on the UiO-66 surface via hydroxyl groups and highly dispersing W around CeO2, showing an excellent SO2 resistance. However, MOFs structures are less thermally stable and are prone to structural collapse at elevated temperature. It was shown that the MOFs derivatives generated from the pyrolysis of MOFs at low calcination temperature could retain the advantages of MOFs [206,207]. The presence of residual C elements in the MOFs derivatives obtained by pyrolysis of MOFs allowed to promoted reactivity and resistance to SO2 and H2O [206]. This was due to the superior electrical conductivity of carbon. The residual carbon with isolated electrons complemented the local charge density and accelerated the electron transfer between the active components. In addition, MOFs derivatives could also be derived from catalysts with different structures by further calcination. Zhang et al. [208] successfully prepared Ti doped CeO2 catalysts with 3D bouquet structure by calcining MOF derivatives of CeO2. Its abundance of Ti3+ induced the production of more Ce3+ ( T i 3 + + C e 4 + ↔ T i 4 + + C e 3 + ), which effectively prevented the electron transfer in the process of the formation of Ce2(SO4)3 from the reaction of SO2 and Ce species. In recent years, three-dimensionally ordered microporous (3DOM) materials have been attracted a great deal of attention in the field of catalysis. Due to the unique structure of 3DOM material, highly ordered microporous-mesoporous structure [209,210], the gas molecules can be homogeneously dispersed on the catalyst surface. This increases the contact area between the catalysts and the small molecules in the gas phase, providing a good gas diffusion channel for gas-solid two-phase catalytic reactions. The enhanced contact contributes to improving the reaction rate and efficiency. In addition, the ordered microporous-mesoporous structure is also conducive to increasing the number of active sites, which are the key locations for catalytic reactions to adsorb and catalyze the transformation of gas-phase molecules. Since water vapor tended to liquefy in small pore, 3DOM materials restrained condensation of H2O on catalysts, which limited the competitive adsorption of H2O with NH3 [211,212]. Our previous research found that the 3DOM Ce-W-Nb catalyst was able to achieve high NO x conversion when exposed to SO2 [213]. Cai et al. [214] reported that the 3DOM CeZrO catalysts with Fe, Co and Mn doping all exhibited pretty SO2 tolerance. These confirmed the unique structural advantages of 3DOM, with the well-arranged large pore sizes for small molecules of reactive gases, which facilitated its efficient catalytic performance despite sulfur poisoning. Moreover, there are a number of other specialized structures that have a vital role to play in improving the reactivity of SCR. Li et al. [215] illustrated the mechanism of improving SO2 resistance of Ce-W-Ti catalyst confined in an ordered mesoporous framework (Ce-W-Ti-E). On the one hand, the framework confined structure strengthened the interaction between Ce, Ti and W, which enhanced the catalyst acidity along with W species, improving the NH3-SCR activity. On the other hand, the special framework structure inhibited SO2 adsorption, weakening the contact between the active sites and SO2, and the superior acidity blocked SO2 adsorption and protected active sites from SO2 attacking. Ma et al. [216] designed the CeO2-TiO2 hollow spheres with large cavity could accelerated the decomposition of ABS, which was the main reason for reducing the loss of activity. This was also consistent with previous report from their group [35]. 4 Conclusions and perspectives The development of Ce-based denitrification catalysts has been extensively studied up to date. SO2 and H2O are unavoidably present in the NH3-SCR flue gas denitrification process, which result in the deactivation of catalysts, lower denitrification efficiency and shorten the life of catalysts. The deactivation of catalyst is a tedious process, and its mechanism of sulfur poisoning is twofold: On the one hand, reversible deactivation caused by the accumulation of AS and ABS on catalysts surface, which decompose at more than 300 °C. On the other hand, irreversible deactivation due to the deposition of metal sulfates. Although NH3 adsorption is favorable and SCR activity is improved in the presence of small amounts of metal sulfate for a short period of time, stable activity cannot be maintained for a long period of time or in the presence of large amounts of SO2. So, there is still a need for some means to prevent the poisoning of SO2 on the Ce-based catalysts during the NH3-SCR reaction. The catalysts are modified by transition metals or non-metals to achieve better sulfur resistance. And changing the catalyst structure is also an effective method. Unique structures allow the catalyst to separate active sites from inactive sites and avoid SO2 adsorption on active components. Despite considerable progress in studying SO2 poisoning mechanism and resistance in Ce-based catalysts, there are some issues that still require immediate attention. Effective NO x removal has been achieved with V-based catalysts in the medium to high temperature range. In the future, more attention should be paid to the application of Ce-based catalysts in NH3-SCR and the improvement of sulfur resistance at low temperatures. Recent studies have addressed the mechanism of SO2 poisoning by means of catalytic characterizations, and few articles have investigated the mechanism of Ce-based catalysts from a microscopic molecular point of view by using DFT. Electron coordination and charge distribution affect the adsorption behavior of reacting and poisoned gases on catalysts. The use of DFT enables better study of electron orbitals and analysis of gas adsorption energies and adsorption configurations. Moreover, the NH3-SCR reaction pathways on the catalyst after sulfation have also been rarely studied at molecular level. The reaction energy barriers of the l-H and E-R mechanisms after sulfation and optimization indicate the degree of difficulty with which a reaction proceeds and deserve to be explored in depth. In addition, it is important to give more attention to the regeneration of anti-poisoning low-temperature SCR catalysts. Hopefully, this review will serve as effective foundation and reference for improving the sulfur tolerance of Ce-based catalysts and promoting the development of related researches. coredata.dc:description: Selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) technology is an effective process for industrial flue gas denitrification. Ce-based catalysts are widely studied due to their excellent redox properties and superior oxygen storage and release capacity (OSC). However, the unavoidable presence of SO2 and H2O in the coal-fired flue gas leads to their limitations in the application of denitrification technology. SO2 poisoning not only causes the formation of metal sulfates, but its synergistic interaction with H2O also results in the deposition of ammonium sulfate species. All this leads to severe deactivation of Ce-based catalysts in NH3-SCR. The development of Ce-based catalysts with excellent sulfur and water resistance is an urgent requirement for SCR technology. This review elucidates the poisoning mechanism of SO2, and analyzes the effects of metals/non-metals modification and structural optimization on the anti-SO2 performance of Ce-based catalysts. This provides the reference and guidance for the subsequent development of Ce-based catalysts resistance to SO2.
